abstracts.cdata!:
The assessment of outcome is
            satisfactory, sustainability likely, with high institutional
            development impacts, although while the Bank performance was
            satisfactory, the Borrower performance is rated
            unsatisfactory, due to the shifting oversight among four
            Ministries, delays in effectiveness and implementation, high
            level of interference, inability to meet the conditions of
            effectiveness, and attempted fraud. Lessons thus convey the
            following. A study is needed to determine the rationale for
            a voucher program/training subsidy, to make a preliminary
            assessment of the source of market failure, supply side or
            demand side, and the extent and cause of market failure,
            i.e., information inadequacy, risk and uncertainty within
            the market, to assess the likelihood of long-term gains from
            a temporary injection of resources, as well consider
            optional approaches including funding or non-funding
            methods. It is also important to keep down overheads and
            transaction costs for a given level of oversight, at the
            same time as finding a structure that most closely resembles
            the market. Consequently, intermediary layers may be used to
            provide information, promote the project, vet applicants and
            issue vouchers, though by and large, intermediaries are not
            necessarily a feature of a market. Options for setting up
            intermediaries are to subcontract them to a separate
            organization, or to set up an allocation infrastructure
            under the managing entity. Private sector management should
            be viewed within the scale of the project management
            responsibility, appropriate to the absorptive capacity of
            the local private sector, and should be subject to
            government/donor financial accounting procedures, have an
            internal procurement system compatible with government/donor
            procedures, and be expected to speed up procurement of goods
            and services. Other lessons include the need for oversight
            and verification processes, moving towards a decentralized,
            self-policing system; conducting pilot projects to assert
            adverse implications for market development; a targeted
            public awareness and information dissemination campaign;
            and, the phase out of a voucher program, rather than a
            jumpstart followed by abrupt closure, would be likely to
            reap superior development impacts.
